titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the North Carolina State University, Athletics, Media Relations Records

editionstmt.p: Finding aid updated to reflect additions to the collection by Cate Putirskis, 2009 November, 2010 August; Updated by Beverly King, 2012 May

controlnote.p: EAD generated by NCSU Libraries' Collection Guides application using data imported from ArchivesSpace.

maintenanceagency.agencyname: North Carolina State University Libraries, Special Collections Research Center

did.unittitle: North Carolina State University, Athletics, Media Relations Records
did.abstract: The North Carolina State University, Athletics, Media Relations Records contain materials related to nearly every sport that has been played at the university, including sports that are no longer active. Types of materials include: press releases, game/event programs, schedules, rosters, clippings, correspondence, brochures, scoring sheets and other game/event notes, photographs, and a variety of other general information documenting the activities of each sport. Materials range in date from 1889 to 2009.

Athletics officially began at the North Carolina College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts (later, North Carolina State University) on March 2, 1892, when a football team made up of students at the college defeated a team from the Raleigh Male Academy. After the college's Board of Trustees made the decision to grant the team requested funds in 1893, North Carolina A&M played its first formal (non-scrimmage) intercollegiate game that fall against the University of North Carolina's football second team. In 1921, NC State became a charter member of the Southern Intercollegiate Conference, remaining until 1953, when along with Duke, UNC-Chapel Hill, Maryland, South Carolina, Wake Forest, and Clemson, the university withdrew to form the Atlantic Coast Conference. In 1974, the first women's athletic teams began play. As of 2009, NC State had eleven men's and eleven women's varsity athletic teams in the Atlantic Coast Conference.
The Media Relations office (formerly, Sports Information) has existed in some form at NC State since the 1940s, as a reference and records-keeping center for statistics and information relating to NC State Athletics.
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Special Collections Research Center Reference Staff.

corpname.part: North Carolina State University Libraries, Special Collections Research Center

acqinfo.p: Transferred from North Carolina State University, Athletics, Media Relations.

arrangement.p: The records of North Carolina State University, Athletics, Media Relations are arranged into the following series (28): News Releases, General Records, Baseball, Men's Basketball, Women's Basketball, Men's Cross Country, Men's Fencing, Football, Men's Golf, Men's Gymnastics, Men's Lacrosse, Men's Rifle, Men's Soccer, Men's Swimming and Diving, Men's Tennis, Men's Track and Field, Wrestling, Women's Gymnastics, Softball, Women's Swimming and Diving, Women's Soccer, Women's Cross Country, Women's Tennis, Women's Track and Field, Women's Fencing, Women's Golf, Volleyball, and Cheerleading. Within each series, materials are arranged chronologically by season, with season-long and general information files preceding files from individual events during that season (where present).

bioghist.p: Athletics began officially at the North Carolina College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts (later renamed North Carolina State University) in 1892 when a group of student formed a football team to play against a local high school. The following year it played its first formal games after the Board of Trustees granted it funds. The baseball team first played in 1894, and men’s basketball in 1911. In the early years the teams used various nicknames, including "Red Terrors." In 1921, the NC State football team began using the name "Wolfpack," and in 1947 this name was officially adopted for all athletic teams. NC State became a charter member of the Southern Conference in 1921, but it left in 1953 to help form the Atlantic Coast Conference. The racial integration of athletics began at NC State in 1958. In 1974, the first women's athletic team (basketball) began play, and the following year women's softball and volleyball were introduced.
For more information on the history of particular sports, see the notes for each one listed on the "Contents" tab.

prefercite.p: [Identification of item], North Carolina State University, Athletics, Media Relations Records, UA 015.010, Special Collections Research Center, North Carolina State University Libraries, Raleigh, NC

processinfo.p: Processed by Cate Putirskis, 2009 June-Nov. Encoded by Cate Putirskis, 2009 June. Finding aid updated by Cate Putirskis, 2009 November; 2010 August

scopecontent.p: The North Carolina State University, Athletics, Media Relations Records contain materials related to nearly every sport played at the university, including sports that are no longer active. Types of materials include: press releases, game/event programs, schedules, rosters, clippings, correspondence, brochures, scoring sheets and other game/event notes, photographs, and a variety of other general information documenting the activities of each sport. Materials range in date from 1889 to 2009.

userestrict.p: The nature of the NCSU Libraries' Special Collections means that copyright or other information about restrictions may be difficult or even impossible to determine despite reasonable efforts. The NCSU Libraries claims only physical ownership of most Special Collections materials.

The materials from our collections are made available for use in research, teaching, and private study, pursuant to U.S. Copyright law. The user must assume full responsibility for any use of the materials, including but not limited to, infringement of copyright and publication rights of reproduced materials. Any materials used for academic research or otherwise should be fully credited with the source.

This collection may contain materials with sensitive or confidential information that is protected under federal or state right to privacy laws and regulations. Researchers are advised that the disclosure of certain information pertaining to identifiable living individuals represented in this collection without the consent of those individuals may have legal ramifications (e.g., a cause of action under common law for invasion of privacy may arise if facts concerning an individual's private life are published that would be deemed highly offensive to a reasonable person) for which North Carolina State University assumes no responsibility.

corpname.part: Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women
North Carolina College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts--History

scopecontent.p: This series contains press and news releases distributed by the Media Relations (formerlly, Sports Information) office covering all university sports, though the majority of the releases cover men's basketball and football. Some duplication of these releases exists in this collection; duplicate releases can be found in the series of the sport they pertain to. Materials are arranged roughly in chronological order. The file of undated releases at the end of this series are from some time prior to 1960; a more exact date cannot be determined.

The General Records series contains Athletics records that do not relate specifically to a single sport; these records either contain information about several sports, or provide general information about the Athletics programs at NC State, as well as the facilities where sporting events were held. This series is arranged roughly chronologically by academic year.

did.abstract: Baseball began at NC State in 1894, with the first official game against Guilford College. Beginning in 1902, the first annual NCSU-Wake Forest Easter Monday game was played, a tradition that continued until 1947. With a record of 14-7, the baseball team claimed their first state championship in 1907. Baseball games were first broadcast on WPTF radio station in 1929. In 1946, the team won the Big Four Conference title, and Doak Field opened as the new baseball facility in 1966. In 1968, under the leadership of head coach Sam Esposito, the baseball team won the Atlantic Coast Conferenc (ACC) title and finished third in the College World Series. From 2003 through 2008, the Wolfpack went to the NCAA tournament every year, a school record for most consecutive trips to the tournament.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the NC State Baseball teams, including clippings, media guides, score books, box scores, player statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, correspondence, and other general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season, with records from individual events (where present) located after the general, season-long records from that particular year.

did.abstract: The first official Men's Basketball game was played in 1911 against Wake Forest, and was held in the old Pullen Hall auditorium. In 1924, home games were moved from Raleigh Memorial Auditorium to the first on-campus facility: Thompson Gymnasium. With a 13-6 record, the basketball team claimed their first Southern Conference championship in 1929. Morris Johnson was NC State's first All-American in basketball in 1930. Everett Case, the winningest coach in NC State basketball history, served as head coach from 1946 until 1965, and in 1950, Coach Case led the Wolfpack to its first Final Four. In 1947, the Men's Basketball team played in a national tournament for the first time (the National Invitational Tournament), and placed third. On December 2, 1949, the first game was played in Reynolds Coliseum (replacing Thompson Gymnasium as the on-campus location for basketball games), against Washington & Lee. In 1954, during the first season of Atlantic Coast Conference play, NC State wins the championship. On January 19, 1956, NC State played their first televised basketball game. David Thompson became the first African American to be named an All-American in any sport at NC State in 1973. In 1974, the basketball team won their first NCAA championship under the leadership of Coach Norman Sloan. From 1981 through 1990, Jim Valvano was the men’s basketball coach, and led the team to an NCAA championship in 1983. On November 19, 1999, the team played thier first home game in the off-campus RBC Center.

scopecontent.p: This series contains the records of the Men's Basketball teams, including statistics, box scores, clippings, score books, individual game files, programs, media guides, schedules, player rosters, photographs, and other publications and general information. Individual game files contain a variety of record types, including box scores, statistics, clippings, programs, correspondence, and printed media from the opposing team(s). Materials are arranged chronologically by season, with the general and season-long records arranged before the records of individual games.

did.abstract: The Women’s Basketball program began in 1974 and was the first women’s athletic team at State. Kay Yow was named as head coach in 1975, a position she held until her death in 2009. In 1976, player Susan Yow, Coach Yow’s younger sister, became the first woman All-American in any sport at State. In the first season of Atlantic Coast Conference league play for Women's Basketball (1978), NC State won the championship. The team played in their first NCAA Tournament game in 1982, and reached the Final Four for the first time in 1998. Coach Kay Yow was inducted into the Woman’s Sports Hall of Fame in 1987, and led the U.S. Olympic Women’s Basketball Team to win gold medals in the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea.

scopecontent.p: This series contains the records of the Women's Basketball teams, including statistics, box scores, clippings, score books, individual game files, programs, media guides, schedules, player rosters, photographs, and other publications and general information. Individual game files contain a variety of record types, including box scores, statistics, clippings, programs, correspondence, and printed media from the opposing team(s). Materials are arranged chronologically by season, with the general and season-long records arranged before the records of individual games.

did.abstract: In 1923, Men's Cross Country became a varsity sport. Steve Francis was the team's first All-American runner in 1980. The team won their first ACC championship in 1986, and in 1987 had their first top 10 finish at the NCAA championship, while finishing the season with a national ranking of fifth.

scopecontent.p: This series contains the records of the Men's Cross Country teams, including statistics, meet information and results, clippings, media guides, schedules, player rosters, itineraries, photographs, and other publications and general information. Individual meet files contain a variety of record types, including statistics, clippings, programs, correspondence, and printed media from the opposing team(s). Materials are arranged chronologically by season, with the general and season-long records arranged before the records of individual meets.

did.abstract: Men's Fencing became a varsity sport in 1952. Varsity competition was discontinued in the mid-1980s, and in the late 1980s fencing was reformed at NC State as a club sport.

scopecontent.p: This series contains the records of the Men's Fencing teams, including statistics, event information and results, clippings, media guides, schedules, player rosters, and other publications and general information. Individual event files contain a variety of record types, including statistics, clippings, and programs. Materials are arranged chronologically by season, with the general and season-long records arranged before the records of individual events.

Atlantic Coast Conference Fencing Championships (5th Annual)

did.abstract: In 1892, the first official football game at NC State was played against a local prep school, Raleigh Male Academy; in 1893, State played their first intercollegiate game against Tennessee. The 1895 team was the first to wear the now traditional red and white colored uniforms, a change from their original pink and blue uniforms. The first on-campus football game was played in 1907 on the field that would later become Riddick Stadium. In 1918, John Ripple becomes the first athlete at NC State to be named an All-American in any sport, and in 1978, Ted Brown becomes the first African American to be named an All-American in football. The football team adopted the nickname “Wolfpack” in 1921, although all other sports continued to use the name “Red Terrors.” In 1930, the first night game was played at Riddick Stadium, and ended in a 37-0 victory against High Point. The team was invited to their first post-season bowl game in 1947, the January 1 Gator bowl against the University of Oklahoma. On October 21 1950, the football team played their first televised game against Maryland. The new Carter Stadium (renamed Carter-Finley Stadium in 1979) opened on October 8, 1966, and in 1967 that Marcus Martin became the first African American member of the football team. In 1967, the team won their first bowl game (the Liberty Bowl) against Georgia with a score of 14-7. The team won their first ACC championship in 1979.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the NC State Football teams, including clippings, media guides, game programs, game and player statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, player questionnaires, depth charts, and other general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season, with records from individual events (where present) located after the general, season-long records from that particular year. Files from individual games and indicated in the title as containing "game information" may include any or all of the above types of records, relating specifically to that contest.

did.abstract: The first Men's Golf team was organized in 1930, but it wasn’t until 1934 that NC State began sponsering golf as a varsity sport. Coach Richard Sykes, who was hired in 1972, remains the coach of the team as of 2009, and is the athletics department’s longest-serving employee. Coach Sykes has won four ACC Coach of the Year awards, produced five ACC Tournament individual champions, one ACC Play of the Year, two ACC Rookies of the Year, 28 All-Americas and more than 40 All-ACC selections.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Men's Golf teams, including clippings, media guides, game programs, game and player statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, player questionnaires, brochures, media guides, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

did.abstract: The Men's Gymnastics team was grated varsity status in 1975, and remained active until 1986, when the Men's Gymnastics program was eliminated.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Men's Gymnastics teams, including clippings, media guides, event information, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, player questionnaires, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

did.abstract: The Men's Lacrosse team was granted varsity status in 1972, and remained at that level into the early 1980s. By the mid-1980s, the Men's Lacrosse varsity program had been eliminated and lacrosse became a club sport at NC State.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Men's Lacrosse teams, including clippings, media guides, event information, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, player questionnaires, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season, with general, season-long records coming before files from individual events (where present).

did.unittitle: NC State vs. Washington & Lee: program
NC State vs. Johns Hopkins (NCAA Division I Lacrosse Championship Tournament)
Wolpack Lacrosse: A Brief History From 1972 Through 1985

did.abstract: Men’s Rifle became a varisty sport in 1958. As a part of the South Eastern Air Rifle Conference (SEARC), the team won their first conference title in 2003-04. In 2006-07, the team joined the Great American Rifle Conference, a top national rifling conference.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Men's Rifle teams, including clippings, media guides, event information, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, player questionnaires, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

did.abstract: Although it was unofficially organized two years early, Men's Soccer became a varsity sport in 1949. Benito Artinatos became the first All-American in soccer at NC State during two consecutive years, 1962 and 1963. In 1990, the team won their first ACC championship.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Men's Soccer teams, including clippings, media guides, game information, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, player questionnaires, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

did.abstract: In 1946, Willis Casey was hired to coach Men's Swimming and Diving, and over the next thirty years, the team won or shared sixteen Southern Conference and Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC) championships. Bob Mattson became NC State's first NCAA champion in the 200-yard breaststroke in 1955. In 1954, the team won the Men’s Outdoor National AAU Championship. After 22 seasons, Casey stepped down as head coach to become Atheletic Director, putting Don Easterling in charge. During Easterling's tenure, the men won the ACC championship 12 consecutive times, 1966-82.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Men's Swimming and Diving teams, including clippings, media guides, meet information, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, player questionnaires, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

did.abstract: The Men's Tennis team began in 1954, under head coach Jack Kenfield. John Sadri was the first player to earn All-American honors in 1977, and advanced to the quaterfinals in the NCAA tournament that year. In 1978, Sadri competed in the NCAA finals against John McEnroe. In 1998, Roberto Bracone was named the Atlantic Coast Conference Player of the Year, the only NC State Men’s Tennis player in school history to win the award. In 2004, the J.W. Isenhour tennis facility opened.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Men's Tennis teams, including clippings, media guides, match information, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, player questionnaires, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

Atlantic Coast Conference Tennis Tournament (21st Annual)

did.abstract: Wrestling was granted varsity status at NC State in 1925. In 1939, the team won the Southern Conference championship and finished second to Appalachian State at the Amateur Atheletic Union (AAU) meet in Greensboro. Bob Guzzo became the head coach in 1975, and in 1976 the team won their first Atlantic Coast Conference championship. In 2004, Guzzo was replaced as head coach by Carter Jordan.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Wrestling teams, including clippings, media guides, meet information, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, player questionnaires, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

did.abstract: Granted varsity status in 1981, the Women’s Gymnastics team has had only one head coach, Mark Stevenson. He has been named the NCAA Southeast Regional Coach of the Year four times, and in 2008 he received the EAGL Coach of the Year for the third consecutive year.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Women's Gymnastics teams, including clippings, media guides, meet information, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

did.abstract: Softball first became a varsity sport in 1976, with Kay Yow serving as coach during the first several seasons. The Softball program remained active until at least 1983, though the program was cancelled sometime in the 1980s, and was not re-established until 2004. In 2004, head coach Lisa Navas resumed the softball program, and Abbie Sims was named a Louisville Slugger/NFCA All-American in 2007. In 2008, the Curtis and Jacqueline Dail Softball Stadium opened, and the team went to the Atlantic Coast Conference championship game during the same season.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Softball teams, including clippings, media guides, game information, scorebooks, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

did.unittitle: NC State Softball Invitational Tournament (6th Annual)
AIAW National Slow-pitch Softball Championship: scorebooks
NC State Softball Invitational Tournament (7th Annual)

did.abstract: The varsity Women's Swimming and Diving program began in 1975. The 1979, team was considered one of the best in the country; they had seven returning All-Americans, won their second consecutive Atlantic Coast Conference Championship title, and placed sixth in the nation at the AIAW meet. In 2009, Kristin Davies, who competed in the platform dive, became the first woman to win an NCAA individual championship in Women's Swimming and Diving at NC State.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Women's Swimming and Diving teams, including clippings, media guides, meet information, questionnaires, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

did.unittitle: Poster: 200-yard Freestyle Relay team sets national record
Atlantic Coast Conference Women's Swimming and Diving Championships
Atlantic Coast Conference Women's Swimming and Diving Championships (5th Annual)

did.abstract: The Women’s Soccer team was established as a varsity sport in 1984. In 1987, the team competed in the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC) tournament with three other teams (there being only four teams in the conference at the time), and placed second. In 1988, the team won the ACC regular-season and tournament championships. The team has gone to the NCAA Tournament 11 times, including eight straight appearances from 1985-1992. The 1988 team is the only Women's Soccer team from NC State to advance to the NCAA championship final.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Women's Soccer teams, including clippings, media guides, game information, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

did.abstract: Women's Cross Country was established as a varsity sport in or before 1977, and during the 1977 season, Joan Benoit and Julie Shea became the first runners to earn All-America honors at NC State. In 1978, the team won the inaugural Atlantic Coast Conferent (ACC) Women’s Cross Country championship. In 1980, Shea won her second consecutive individual national championship and helped defend the team’s second consecutive national championship. In 1981, Betty Springs becomes the first NCAA women’s champion at NC State, and earned a championship again in 1983. Suzie Tuffey became the first freshman to win a NCAA national championship in 1986, and gave NC State their fifth individual national championship in nine years. The Women's Cross Country team won the ACC championship each seaon from 1987-1993, 1995-1998, and 2000-2001, giving them 21 championships out of the possible 29 years that Women's Cross Country has been an ACC sport. The team has gone to the NCAA championships 23 times since the organization started recognizing Women’s Cross Country in 1981.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Women's Cross Country teams, including clippings, media guides, meet information, questionnaires, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

did.unittitle: North Carolina Intercollegiate State Cross Country Championships
Wolfpack High School Cross Country Invitational Meet
North Carolina State Intercollegiate Cross Country Championship

did.abstract: The Women’s Tennis program began in 1977. In 1998, head coach Jenny Garrity recieved the Atlantic Coast Conference Coach of the Year award, and led the team to the NCAA Tournament. The team advanced to the NCAA Tournament in 2006, 2007, and 2008, under the direction of head coach Hans Olsen. In 1994 and 1995, Kylie Hunt made it to the NCAA Tournament for Singles. In 2007, Alejandra Guerra and Daria Petrovic went to the NCAA Tournament for Doubles.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Women's Tennis teams, including clippings, media guides, match information, questionnaires, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

did.abstract: Women's Track and Field was established as a varsity sport in or before 1979. In 1979, Julie Shea won the AIAW national title for the 5,000 meters; in 1980, she also won the 3,000 5,000 and 10,000 meters national titles. In 1981, Shea won the 5,000 meters AIAW national title. In 1983, Betty Springs won the 5,000 and 10,000 meters NCAA championship, and was ranked number one in the United States and third in the world for the 5,000 meters by the Track and Field News. Women's Track and Field team member Joan Benoit won a gold medal at the 1984 Los Angeles Summer Olympics. In 1985, the NC State 4x100 meter team won the NCAA championship, and in 1991, Laurie Gomez won the 5,000 meters NCAA championship. Tyrell Taitt won the triple jump championship in 1993, and Kristin Price won the 10,000 meters national title in 2002.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Women's Track and Field teams, including clippings, media guides, meet information, questionnaires, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

did.abstract: Women's Fencing was established as a varsity sport in or before 1979, and retained varsity status through at least the 1983 season.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Women's Fencing teams, including media guides and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

did.abstract: In 1984, Women's Golf became a recognized sport by the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC), with four teams competing (Duke, UNC-Chapel Hill, NC State, and Wake Forest), but was discontinued by the ACC in 1986. Although Women's Golf returned to the other three schools in 1992, NC State did not re-establish a team again until 2001. Page Marsh became the head coach when the team was reinstated, and led them to seven straight appearences in the NCAA Tournament (2001-2007). Although the team did not make it to the NCAA Tournament in 2008, Lauren Doughtie became the first individual golfer at NC State to make it to the NCAA Tournament.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Women's Golf teams, including clippings, media guides, meet information, questionnaires, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

did.abstract: Volleyball was established as a varsity sport at NC State in 1976, with Kay Yow serving as coach during the first seasons. Volleyball remained a varsity sport as of 2009.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Volleyball teams, including clippings, media guides, game information, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.

did.abstract: In 1898, the first Men's Track team was organized for intercollegiate competition; however, it was disbanded after the season and track did not reappear at NC State until 1905. In 1923, Men's Track and Field was granted varsity status. The team won championships in the Southern Conference for the first time in 1951, and the Atlantic Coast Conference in its innaugural year of 1953.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Men's Track and Field teams, including clippings, media guides, event information, statistics, press releases, rosters, schedules, player questionnaires, brochures, and other publications and general information. Materials are arranged chronologically by season.
